q: Which is the first stage of the AI Project Cycle?
options: Data Acquisition|Problem Scoping|Modelling|Evaluation
explain: Problem Scoping comes first because you must define the problem before collecting data.

q: The AI Project Cycle primarily contains how many core stages?
explain: The cycle generally includes Problem Scoping, Data Acquisition, Modelling, and Evaluation.

q: Which stage focuses on defining stakeholders, goals and constraints?
options: Data Exploration|Problem Scoping|Evaluation|Deployment
explain: Problem Scoping identifies what the problem is, who it affects, and what limits exist.

q: The 4Ws Problem Canvas stands for:
options: Who, What, Where, Why|Who, When, What, Why|Who, What, When, Where|What, Why, When, How
explain: The 4Ws help break down the problem into Who, What, Where, and Why.

q: In the 4Ws Canvas, the Who block identifies:
options: Data sources|Algorithms|Stakeholders affected by the problem|Hardware requirements
explain: The Who section refers to people involved or impacted by the solution.

q: Which stage involves collecting reliable and relevant data?
options: Evaluation|Data Acquisition|Modelling|Problem Scoping
explain: Data Acquisition is the stage where data is gathered from various sources.

q: During Data Acquisition, which of the following is a valid data type?
options: Text only|Text, images, audio, video|Images only|Numbers only
explain: Data can come in many formats including text, images, audio, and video.

q: Which stage focuses on summarising, cleaning, and visualising the data?
options: Modelling|Data Exploration|Evaluation|Problem Scoping
explain: Data Exploration helps understand and clean the data before modelling.

q: Creating and training a Decision Tree model happens in:
options: Modelling|Evaluation|Problem Scoping|Data Acquisition
explain: Modelling involves selecting and training algorithms like Decision Trees.

q: Splitting data into train and test sets is part of:
options: Data Exploration|Modelling|Evaluation|Problem Scoping
explain: Evaluating a model requires testing it on unseen (test) data.

q: Which metric is used for evaluating classification models?
options: Mean Absolute Error|Precision and Recall|RMSE|R^2
explain: Precision and Recall are used for classification tasks.

q: The Why block in 4Ws helps to:
options: Pick algorithms|Identify benefits and impact of solving the problem|Collect data|Deploy the model
explain: Why helps identify the purpose and expected impact of solving the problem.

q: A problem statement template is used to:
options: Write code|Condense 4Ws insights into a clear statement|Store datasets|Design UI
explain: It summarises the 4Ws into one clear problem description.

q: Which stage often uses graphs like bar charts or histograms?
options: Data Exploration|Modelling|Evaluation|Data Acquisition
explain: Graphs help explore data patterns during Data Exploration.

q: In evaluation, Accuracy is best defined as:
options: TP/(TP+FP)|TP/(TP+FN)|(TP+TN)/(TP+FP+FN+TN)|FP/(TP+FP)
explain: Accuracy measures the total proportion of correct predictions.

q: The Confusion Matrix is used to evaluate:
options: Regression models|Classification models|Clustering models|Rule-based systems only
explain: A confusion matrix shows correct and incorrect predictions for classification.

q: Which term means the model performs well on training data but poorly on new data?
options: Generalisation|Underfitting|Overfitting|Normalization
explain: Overfitting happens when a model memorises training data instead of learning patterns.

q: Which is an example of a supervised learning algorithm commonly taught in Class 10?
options: K-Means|Decision Tree|DBSCAN|Apriori
explain: Decision Trees learn from labelled data and are supervised algorithms.

q: Valid sources for Data Acquisition include:
options: Surveys and sensors|Random guesses|Only paid datasets|Only social media
explain: Survey responses and sensor readings are valid reliable data sources.

q: One goal of Problem Scoping is to link the project to:
options: Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs)|Only hardware lists|Only software licenses|None of the above
explain: Projects often connect to global challenges defined in the SDGs.

q: The AI Project Cycle is best described as:
options: A one-time linear process|An iterative framework|Only for experts|A hardware checklist
explain: The cycle is iterative, meaning you refine steps based on results.

q: During Modelling, you should choose algorithms based on:
options: Random choice|Problem type and data characteristics|Font styles|GPU brand
explain: The right algorithm depends on whether the problem is classification, regression, etc.

q: In supervised learning, classification vs regression differs by:
options: Inputs used|Type of output (categories vs continuous values)|Who collects data|How visualisations look
explain: Classification predicts categories, while regression predicts continuous values.

q: Handling missing values usually belongs to:
options: Data Exploration|Problem Scoping|Evaluation|Deployment
explain: Cleaning missing data happens during Data Exploration.

q: Bias in AI systems often arises when:
options: Training data is not representative|We use charts|We split data|We write comments
explain: Bias appears when data does not cover all groups fairly.

q: Precision is defined as:
options: TP/(TP+FN)|(TP+TN)/(Total)|TP/(TP+FP)|FP/(TP+FN)
explain: Precision tells how many predicted positives were actually correct.

q: Recall is defined as:
options: TP/(TP+FN)|TP/(TP+FP)|FP/(TP+FN)|TN/(TN+FP)
explain: Recall measures how many actual positives were correctly identified.

q: The F1 Score is:
options: Arithmetic mean of precision and recall|Harmonic mean of precision and recall|Geometric mean of accuracy|A loss function
explain: The F1 score balances precision and recall using the harmonic mean.

q: The purpose of a train–test split is to:
options: Improve UI|Fairly evaluate model performance on unseen data|Collect more data|Increase training speed only
explain: A test set helps measure how well the model performs on new data.

q: A rule-based approach uses:
options: Explicit if–then rules|Neural networks|Decision boundaries learned from data|Random forests only
explain: Rule-based systems work on fixed if–then rules.

q: During Data Acquisition, we must respect:
options: Only speed|Privacy, permissions, and data ethics|UI themes|Font licensing
explain: Ethical data handling ensures privacy and proper permissions.

q: Error analysis (understanding mistakes) belongs to:
options: Evaluation|Problem Scoping|Data Acquisition|Modelling
explain: Evaluation includes checking where the model made mistakes.

q: Stakeholders are:
options: Only developers|People affected by or benefiting from the solution|Only teachers|Only customers
explain: Stakeholders include anyone impacted by the AI solution.

q: The Where block in 4Ws helps to understand:
options: Model hyperparameters|Deployment cloud vendor|Context and environment of the problem|Programming language
explain: Where describes the environment or setting of the problem.

q: Common data types for AI projects include:
options: Only text|Text, numeric tables, images, audio, video|Only audio|Only video
explain: AI can work with multiple data types, not just text.

q: Modelling includes:
options: Algorithm selection and training|Only drawing charts|Writing the problem statement|Buying hardware
explain: Modelling involves choosing and training algorithms.

q: Visualisation is used to:
options: Hide patterns|Uncover patterns and insights in data|Replace evaluation|Skip modelling
explain: Charts help detect trends and patterns in data.

q: After Evaluation, the typical next action is to:
options: Publish regardless|Iterate—refine earlier stages based on findings|Delete data|Ignore ethics
explain: Evaluation results help improve earlier stages in the cycle.

q: Which stage is most closely associated with cleaning data?
options: Problem Scoping|Data Exploration|Modelling|Evaluation
explain: Data cleaning is a major part of Data Exploration.

q: Selecting appropriate features for the model primarily belongs to:
options: Modelling/Data Exploration|Problem Scoping|Deployment|None
explain: Feature selection is split between Data Exploration and Modelling.
